column5:
Merge pull request #31 from hamo/pickle-compliant

Force pickle.dump uses protocol 2
Plumb env and cwd through create as well.

Merge pull request #22 from amscanne/fix_python3

Make python scripts python3 compatible.

Make python scripts python3 compatible.

With the assistance of the python module six (seems to be mostly standard), the
python module is now python2 and python3 compatible. No magic __future__.

Fix go1.3 and go1.4 compatibility issue.

The garbage collector was cleaning up the console file. We lift it out
of the if scope, and noguest works again.

This should fix #7, #10 and #23.

Merge pull request #21 from davidkuridza/fix-pkg-info-url

Fix pkg-info's project URL

Merge pull request #18 from hamo/mkinit_fix

Make modules dir before copy modules into it

Merge pull request #4 from attilaolah/master

Fix a typo in the README

Fix nic documentation, and debug parameter.

This addresses #9.

Revert a54fb35.

This was causing a problem and leading to #19. I need to properly test and
debug this prior to remerging this change.

Fix pkg-info's project URL

When trying to access http://code.google.com/p/novm/, 404 is returned.
It seems the project at code.google.com is abandonded in favour of
hosting it at GitHub.

Merge pull request #20 from rmahmood/master

Make sure DEBIAN directory has correct permissions during build.

Make sure DEBIAN directory has correct permissions during build.

Git appears to check out directories with permission 750. Dpkg
requires the DEBIAN directory to be accessible by everyone.
Make modules dir before copy modules into it

Switch from MMIO PCI bars to PIO PCI bars.

This results in a substantial performance improvement.

Emulation of MMIO accesses is much slower, as the actual instruction
must be emulated. PIO accesses can be emulated much faster, since the
data is well-defined and inline.

Merge pull request #17 from amscanne/fix_rpm_spec_2

Drop confusing novm-docker script, cleanup RPM build.

Make rpm files explicit.

I'm not sure why it fails on Fedora (given it builds fine on systems
that I tested), but apparently it does.

This drops the filelist part for explicit file parts.

Remove confusing docker script.

This mechanism for running docker images was explored, but ultimately a
different approach was taken. This script is confusing and shouldn't
really be here anymore.

Merge pull request #13 from amscanne/clarify_reqs

Add note re: older kernels.

Merge pull request #6 from tdubrownik/master

Switching from arch to go env GOARCH

Merge pull request #14 from amscanne/fix_rpmspec

This is a fix for #12.

Merge pull request #15 from amscanne/contributors

Clarify contribution process.
Include only files in rpm spec.

Switching from arch to go env GOARCH

This is a very tiny change that should make building more portable.
Since go is an implicit dependency, we may as well use its idea of host
architecture instead of an OSX command.
Use proper include path for bootparam.h.

Change spaces to tabs.

It seems gofmt no longer supports -tabs=false. So it's time to do it the
right way. More idiomatic with tabs anyways.

Pass through terminal setting for NOVM RUN.

This simplifies starting up processes from noguest when we
don't care about having a terminal. Unfortunately, we still
have a problem with noguest execve() always failing after
some unknown terminal manipulation. Children are still not
being isolated properly in the terminal case.

Change-Id: Ica253edc3e709b3ef06a7dd4e9dbe836814f788e

Support proper reading of symlinks.

This adds support for reading and stating symlinks as expected by
9pfs. This doesn't add support for creating symlinks, that will come
in a later commit.

Change-Id: I7c84086fdb60126c6da0cd81078c88d73473235c

Handle renames appropriately.

If we're renaming onto a deleted file, we need to clear out the
underlying file. Similarly, we need to mark the moved file as deleted.

Change-Id: Ia13bec00e95ea0aab857a4f8c98e9022f5835778

Initial wstat() implementation.

This at least allows touch (and rename, almost) to work.

All of these operations have become quite complex in commit,rollback
logic. At some point in the future, it would make sense to create an
interface for all the Operations to implement, along the lines of:

   Prepare(), Commit() | Rollback()

Then the parse methods would simply return an interface object which
would be called appropriately. Anyways, this is work for a future
commit.

Change-Id: I153e9378f2e16ca02bef1d7e183f2c8efba7e41d

Working eventfd implementation.

Since this works, I've also removed the flag that allows you
to enable or disable eventfds. This prevents a bounce out of the
kernel to handle device emulation (i.e. notifying the virtio
backend that a new buffer has been added), so should improve
latency decently. There's no solid reason to disable it.

Change-Id: I4656b30c2ee18fe3e287dd99d4afc38ae4f1e9da

Fixing device initialization in management code (trivial).

Change-Id: Ic66d9f5e4dcc683ae6dac4c6110fbcff8b1e4869

Catch only relevant signals.

Unintended consequence: previously, we were catching all signals.

This means that we were catching SIGINT when trying to Ctrl-C
from the command line, which could be quite frustrating.

Change-Id: Iaee52e699e6cbbac9c4010b8da3941f199f00916

Refactor python commannd line management wrapper.

This splits the command line logic and management logic
into two separate components. Although this is intended as
a lightweight management stack (and not really for use cases
beyond development or simple ones), this should allow tools
to hook into the NovmManager() more cleanly.

Change-Id: Iacd7ae29ae3e6b15e7681d583ee4056a164abdf1

Fix signal handler for parent death.

There was a race condition on STOP/CONT of parent (or spurious
signals delivered to child processes). This refactors the loop
in order to handle the case where we get a TERM but the parent
hasn't exited just yet. Hopefully without any other races.

Change-Id: I22aa0bf6d069688e1d92122e01418b9fc25798f1

Implement a special restart mode.

This allows us to effectively keep VMs running and upgrade KVM.
While this probably isn't super useful without a larger management
framework, this at least gives us a compelling use case for the
SIGHUP restart functionality (which was largely introduced for
simple testing and verification of all the state serialization).

This also moves signal catching as close as possible to the start
of the program, in order to reduce the chance of missing them.
(This sort of sucks, but I don't really want to go plubming into
the depths of the runtime in order to fix this problem).

Change-Id: Id1c7d778107cd51d2aa6d65c8db81b3bd4de7b5a

Omnibus commit for state synchronization.

Unfortunately, this got a big out of control while attempting
to get suspend / resume working properly. This commits contains
several (high-related) items that are difficult to split up:

* Fix the interface used for synchronized device state to
  the underlying VM. This means instead of a Sync() call, we
  now have formal Load() and Save() methods which will Load()
  the device state into the VM, and pull out the state from
  within the VM respectively.

* Add a device Pause() functionality. Because we need to ensure
  that devices are not actively changing state when we serialize
  state, we need to add a Pause() and Unpause() hook to the model
  similar to the Vcpu state. This also requires that goroutines
  that are using the underlying device call appropriate Acquire()
  and Release() methods when they are mutating the state. (These
  should not block, and should only be held when the device is
  actively changing).

  You don't need to worry about this for standard Read(), Write()
  methods, only for additional goroutines that you may launch.

  These pause methods are exposed via the control plane, and a
  paused flag is added to the command line for development.

  (It's useful to start a VM in a paused state).

* Add new KVM state & devices (like the FPU state) that were not
  properly being accounted for before.

* Fixes for small serialization errors encountered during development.

  Including:

  * Invalid refs serialized for plan9 state.
  * Cpuid saved all register state to eax, stupdly.
  * MSRs weren't look at nr_msrs correctly, so no MSRs
    were being loaded correctly.
  * When the console device was opened, the load was held
    waiting for Opened = true, but that had already happened.

* Refactor and reorganize related bits of code to be cleaner.

Change-Id: Ic4acfab2a6557891a8d7771e91c3d63f27de7249

Need buffered channel for restore.

Because we inject a nil error on restore, we need this
channel to be buffered. (There were other ways of doing
this, but this is just a trivial fix).

Change-Id: I89b30a130411abc4727799f434cde28d5745c0b6

Create utils package.

This package contains helpers for encoding & decoding, as well
as a simple Die() method to wrap around log.Fatal (or maybe panic).

Undoubtedly this package will grow in the future.

Change-Id: I1c833e3ef7636e6dbd6dc4c1c32b54cba5c7f93d

Control refactor: split types into Rpc and Control.

It was getting a bit frustrating having to ensure that
all public methods of the Control matched the rpc spec.

This commit splits the control types into the server and
an RPC object, which the actual control calls hang from.
This makes the separate very clear (and ensures that we
won't actually expose methods that shouldn't be exposed).

Change-Id: I10a826a3ae21df9d8d3115555f27633e07b5b0e3

Wide changes to support saving full CPU state.

In order for suspend & resume to work properly, we need to correctly
serialize all the state contained with the Linux kernel in addition to
the userspace state. This adds the appropriate hooks to all that to happen
as with other devices (but actually triggered from the BIOS).

Change-Id: I18125e91651c9fffeff9343f07125de4dbea48ee

Implement zero-downtime upgrades.

As a mechanism for providing zero-downtime upgrades, as well as exercising
built-in suspend/resume mechanisms we support hitting novmm with a SIGHUP
and causing a re-exec() of the process with the current state.

Note that this required that we change the way state is passed in to the
novmm process. In order to ensure that we can use arbitrarily-sized state,
we now accept an FD instead of a bloating the command line.

Change-Id: Ie526e7bb96eb3037a3e9e190d5b4d299e3ffb68e

Fix close-on-exec semantics for all file descriptors.

For all file descriptors which we open internally, we ensure
that these are marked CLOEXEC. This is being done as part of
efforts to perform live restarts (and exercise suspend/resume).

Change-Id: I64759cb51e43fe454c99a11b52955a4f80875896

Refactor state and fix serialization issues.

Many of the device objects had issues with serialization.

This commit addresses most of those issues (implementing a custom
marshal or unmarshal method where necessary) and refactors the internal
state. Instead of using a separate devices and vcpus object, we now use
just a single state object which contains both devices and vcpus.

Change-Id: I9ee1f1852f85365863e1dae22aa7269c0f1967f3

Refactor control files into separate package.

These were becoming more numerous than I had originally intended.
It makes sense to split all the control functions into a separate
package. This commit contains only one functional change:

* A basic control was added that allows for pausing/unpausing.

Change-Id: I86ba6f7e25d9cabeba0d6392a5c89a257538a51b

Fix build on older system.

If you pass KERNEL=y, we will now build against kernel headers
(either guessed or as passed by the user). This is optional because
it some cases it may lead to problems (if your system headers are
much older than the kernel headers assume).

Change-Id: I4604ae8df45ceddcbda25f103239b394b6e8413c

Sync registers after interrupting KVM_RUN.

If we pause a VCPU (i.e. deliver a signal and cause EINTR to return),
we need to synchronize the register state and mark the current cache
as invalid. Otherwise, calls to GetRegisters() will return stale data.

Change-Id: I14ea66e79929ef974ae972fc31fa6e19cc61be07

Remove unused files.

These were necessary at some point, but are no longer needed.
At some point we may invest effort in using AIO in order to do
block I/O, but frankly the level of asynchrony provided by Go
itself renders most of that unnecessary.

Change-Id: If30a4805455028068b38bb8daf3ab3650810b704

Add @alwaysjson decorator for commands.

For commands that don't really have a sensible prettyprint
output (like control), we can simply have them default to use
JSON output. This is a simple decorator which changes behaviour.

Change-Id: If1bc23b0088d505c57e8e6315840200409bd9e89

Probe rlimit on attach(), not on init().

The structure will be deserialization post-init(), so we may
end up with a fdlimit of 0. This doens't make sense -- the intended
behaviour was to treat this as an "auto" mode. So we need to probe
the rlimit on attach(), not on init().

Change-Id: Ic05bacd122ef3746f941abdc36179771e6f5d496

Clear LRU index on removal.

Whoops. If something gets flushed from the LRU, we don't clear
the index. This can result in a potential SEGV (among many other
potential problems) when the file is removed a second time at close.

Change-Id: I37e94e40c1ac805395c8b9f996e8c74d4e701b09

Add GetRegisters(), SetRegisters() functions.

This makes it easier to take an atomic snapshot of all
available registers for a given VCPU. This relies on the
new Pause()/Unpause() functionality.

Change-Id: I7ea31533e7f9beb7929b780599025eef9b1c9ca8

Fix pause semantics.

Turns out, we couldn't reliably interrupt KVM in the kernel
simply by setting stepping on or off. It's somewhat difficult
to get around the Go scheduler in this case, so we need to isolate
some critical pieces inside C extensions to avoid thread switching.

This leads to some fairly complex-seeming pause-related code, but
in the end I believe that this is necessary.

Change-Id: I1709df4ec7fea6827f38f6f984c48e5ab8dbe241

Squash SIGINT and cleanup only on parent death.

We were getting both a SIGINT and SIGTERM when the user ctrl-C's
a running novm at a terminal. This was resulting in the cleanup
handler dying some part of the time.

Change-Id: Iff006fb754f642d672d0b0f45c7aa1b6ec8180cf

Implement file desriptor limits.

There are undoubtedly still bugs in the filesystem backend,
but this sketches out a simple implementation of an LRU cache
for actual fds. When we go over the limit, we will close unlocked
file fds (which can be subsequently reopened if the kernel reads
again).

Change-Id: I23094c49b0ad8334d6e66bdbba826956a2c6d6fe

Forward guest nic hardware offload features.

Configuring the tap device to allow the guest nic to make use of
hardware offload features (such as hardware checksumming and
segmentation offloading) on the host's physical nic.

Change-Id: Ic16ba65bf3b415af556ae001ec39589da898a0f2

Adding default .gitreview for Gerrit.

Change-Id: If364770ab121ae7800b6128c1e02655b4315663b

Add experimental docker backend.

This allows novm to function as an "execdriver" for Docker.

For more information, see the docker blog post available here:
   http://blog.docker.io/2014/03/docker-0-9-introducing-execution-drivers-and-libcontainer/

This functionality requires a "shell" execdriver.

This is currently a pull request, available here:
   https://github.com/dotcloud/docker/pull/4626
Use absolute values (PATH may not be defined).
Give more information in run() exceptions.
Add MTU to supported NIC parameters.
Show full exception, even with fork().

Drop sync.Once use where it's really not needed.

This is only called a very limited number of times,
so just call the same function multiple times. It makes
the logic clearer and drops the extra globals.
Don't copy full source on import.

Enable passing a command to create().

This will also ensure that the VMM exits when the command is finished,
and the shell exit code should match the process exit code.

Fixing parsing for extra arguments.

Now you don't need to pass -- in order to stop processing.

Restructure control flow.

Unfortunately, there's still a problem. It seems that
the first client connected prior to NOGUEST coming up,
will simply hang. Blerg.

Change init semantics.

We now allow either real_init, or not. No isolation in PID
namespaces and mount namespaces, seems that's needlessly complex.

Remove unnecessary interrupt.

Where did it come from?
Support arbitrary JSON for control objects.

Split control into multiple files.

This is in antipication of more control command, a
more complex interface, etc.
Add basic support for sucking down Docker containers.

Implement PCI 2 MSI-X specification.

Which begs the question, what the hell was I implementing before?

Add MSI-X support for PCI devices.

This isn't working properly with Linux, but it seems to be the
case that the guest-side is not even probing PCI capabilities.

I suspect that our broken ACPI data is causing Linux to be pretty
conservation about hardware-related decisions.

Small fixes for non-root execution.

* Include set -e in scripts.
* No need to open r+ when reading.
Add safety around initial console calls.
Working implementation of Plan9FS with Virtio backend.
Working virtqueues (guest=>host). That wasn't so bad.
DSDT should not be in root, only via FADT.
Improve ACPI support, still not there yet.
Fix cleanup scripts hanging on terminal.
Closure problem when running multiple vcpus.
Fix formatting. Also, what's an L2 hypervisor?
